escenes.text: Once upon a time, there was a sweet and cheerful little girl whom everyone called Little Red Riding Hood, because she always wore a red cloak with a hood that her grandmother had lovingly made for her. She liked to walk through the forest, greet the animals, and help her mother whenever she could.

One day, her mother said kindly: ‘Little Red Riding Hood, take this basket filled with bread, fruit, and honey to your grandmother, who is sick and needs to get better. But don’t get distracted in the forest and be very careful.’ ‘Yes, mother, don’t worry,’ answered the girl happily, eager to see her grandmother and bring her everything she needed.

As she walked along the forest path, Little Red Riding Hood met a wolf. ‘Good morning, Little Red Riding Hood,’ said the wolf in a soft voice, though his eyes gleamed with mischief. ‘Where are you going with that heavy basket?’ ‘I’m going to my grandmother’s house, which is on the other side of the forest, to bring her this food,’ replied the girl without suspecting a thing. ‘What a lovely idea,’ said the wolf slyly. ‘Why don’t you also pick some beautiful flowers? I’m sure your grandmother would love them.’

Delighted with the suggestion, Little Red Riding Hood began picking colorful flowers to surprise her grandmother. Meanwhile, the wolf ran quickly to the grandmother’s house. When he arrived, he knocked at the door, pretending to be the little girl. ‘Who is it?’ asked the grandmother from inside. ‘It’s me, Little Red Riding Hood,’ answered the wolf, trying to sound sweet and gentle.

The grandmother, believing it was her granddaughter, opened the door without hesitation. But the moment she did, the wolf jumped on her and swallowed her whole. Then he put on her cap and glasses, and slipped into bed, pretending to be the grandmother so he could trick the little girl when she arrived.

When Little Red Riding Hood came into the house, she was very surprised to see her grandmother looking so strange. ‘Grandmother, what big eyes you have!’ ‘The better to see you with, my dear.’ ‘And what big ears you have!’ ‘The better to hear you with, my child.’ ‘But grandmother, what a big mouth you have!’ ‘The better to eat you with!’ growled the wolf, jumping out of bed.

At that very moment, the wolf tried to catch the girl. Luckily, a hunter passing by heard the cries and rushed into the house. Bravely, he drove the wolf away and cut open his huge belly, from which he pulled the grandmother safe and sound. Little Red Riding Hood hugged her grandmother tightly, overjoyed to see her again.

Grateful and still a little frightened by what had happened, Little Red Riding Hood promised her mother that she would never again get distracted along the way and that she would always follow her advice. From then on, the three of them —the mother, the grandmother, and Little Red Riding Hood— lived peacefully and happily, and the wolf never dared come near them again.
Illustrations: Paula C., Voice: Noelia D.
